body:
### Problem

_I apologize if this isn't the right way to report this kind of crashes. I haven't been able to pinpoint exactly what's causing these errors._

After updating Neovim yesterday (which I did after https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/7a76fb8547548304450b59624f9c75a554396504), I've been having regular crashes where Neovim will just SIGABRT. It seems to happen when I'm saving a file that has errors.

### Steps to reproduce

I truly apologize for the lack of repro steps here. I do have the following crash report from the Mac console (all reports have a similar stack trace):

comment_data.body: @bfredl the stack trace and timing makes me think that maybe #13243 might be causing this?

Dunno if it helps, but your offset `marktree_intersect_pair + 560` points to (ignore the mis-annotations from objdump):

```
    135 1002a55f8: e0 10 00 b0  adrp    x0, 0x1004c2000 <_split_node+0x42c>
    136 1002a55fc: 00 c4 1c 91  add     x0, x0, #1841
    137 1002a5600: e1 10 00 b0  adrp    x1, 0x1004c2000 <_split_node+0x434>
    138 1002a5604: 21 40 13 91  add     x1, x1, #1232
    139 1002a5608: e3 10 00 b0  adrp    x3, 0x1004c2000 <_split_node+0x43c>
    140 1002a560c: 63 70 1d 91  add     x3, x3, #1884
    141 1002a5610: a2 2c 80 52  mov     w2, #357
   >>> 142 1002a5614: d3 aa 06 94  bl      0x100450160 <_writev+0x100450160> <<<
```

which is logging an assertion failure at `marktree.c:357`:

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/a6e74c1f0a2bbf03f5b99c167b549018f4c8fb0d/src/nvim/marktree.c#L357

EDIT: sorry, original instruction was off by one
@llllvvuu definitely helpful. For my own knowledge: How did you compute the insulting line?

Hey @MariaSolOs, using [binutils](https://formulae.brew.sh/formula/binutils):

```sh
objdump -d -S ./build/bin/nvim > dump
less -N dump
```
Search "<marktree_intersect_pair>:" to find:
```
702302 00000001002a53e8 <_marktree_intersect_pair>:
```
```
python -c "print(hex(0x1002a53e8 + 560))"   # 0x1002a5618
```
search "1002a5618" to find:
```
1002a55f8: e0 10 00 b0  adrp    x0, 0x1004c2000 <_split_node+0x42c>
1002a55fc: 00 c4 1c 91  add     x0, x0, #1841
1002a5600: e1 10 00 b0  adrp    x1, 0x1004c2000 <_split_node+0x434>
1002a5604: 21 40 13 91  add     x1, x1, #1232
1002a5608: e3 10 00 b0  adrp    x3, 0x1004c2000 <_split_node+0x43c>
1002a560c: 63 70 1d 91  add     x3, x3, #1884
1002a5610: a2 2c 80 52  mov     w2, #357
1002a5614: d3 aa 06 94  bl      0x100450160 <_writev+0x100450160>
>>> 1002a5618: e0 10 00 b0  adrp    x0, 0x1004c2000 <_split_node+0x44c> <<<
1002a561c: 00 c4 1c 91  add     x0, x0, #1841
1002a5620: e1 10 00 b0  adrp    x1, 0x1004c2000 <_split_node+0x454>
1002a5624: 21 40 13 91  add     x1, x1, #1232
1002a5628: e3 10 00 b0  adrp    x3, 0x1004c2000 <_split_node+0x45c>
1002a562c: 63 08 1d 91  add     x3, x3, #1858
1002a5630: e2 2a 80 52  mov     w2, #343
1002a5634: cb aa 06 94  bl      0x100450160 <_writev+0x100450160>
```
IDK why it's off by one, but "bl" in arm64 means "call function with arguments x0, x1, x2 ..." and w0, w1, w2... are just lower bits of x0, x1, x2....

This is a call `some_syscall(interned[1841], interned[1232], 357, interned[1884])`. Since 357 and 343 are both line numbers and they both point to assertion lines, we can infer that this is assert macro, which BTW is defined on MacOS as:
```c
#if __DARWIN_UNIX03
#define	assert(e) \
    (__builtin_expect(!(e), 0) ? __assert_rtn(__func__, __ASSERT_FILE_NAME, __LINE__, #e) : (void)0)
```

Hope that explains it.
@llllvvuu impressive. Thanks for sharing!
Thanks of the report. What is the build type (second line of `:version` ) ?
@bfredl It must be `RelWithDebInfo` based on the instruction addresses.
@bfredl no prob. And yep, as @llllvvuu said, I'm using `RelWithDebInfo`.
Yes, but RelWithDebInfo is supposed to have line numbers info, not just instruction addresses. The combination of asserts (not NDBUG) but no line number info in tracebacks is not very helpful.

@bfredl the Mac Console includes this as well. I didn't include it above since it felt like it was just duplicating the content, but maybe this is what you're looking for?

@llllvvuu @bfredl Okay I seem to be able to kind of reproduce it by doing something like this. The steps are not very concrete and it requires some fiddling.

1. Create a `lua` file with the following contents:
```lua
---@param node TSNode Starting node to begin traversal |tsnode|
---@param depth integer Current recursion depth
---@param lang string Language of the tree currently being traversed
---@param injections table<integer,TSP.Node> Mapping of node ids to root nodes of injected language trees (see
---                        explanation above)
---@param tree TSP.Node[] Output table containing a list of tables each representing a node in the tree
local function traverse(node, depth, lang, injections, tree)
  local injection = injections[node:id()]
  if injection then
    traverse(injection.root, depth, injection.lang, injections, tree)
  end

  for child, field in node:iter_children() do
    local type = child:type()
    local lnum, col, end_lnum, end_col = child:range()
    local named = child:named()
    local text ---@type string
    if named then
      if field then
        text = string.format('%s: (%s)', field, type)
      else
        text = string.format('(%s)', type)
      end
    else
      text = string.format('"%s"', type:gsub('\n', '\\n'))
    end

    table.insert(tree, {
      id = child:id(),
      text = text,
      named = named,
      depth = depth,
      lnum = lnum,
      col = col,
      end_lnum = end_lnum,
      end_col = end_col,
      lang = lang,
    })

    traverse(child, depth + 1, lang, injections, tree)
  end

  return tree
end
```
The contents are arbitrary of course, I'm just stuffing a random function from `dev.lua`. The repro does seem to require for the entire file not to be entirely visible in the screen (i.e. you need to scroll to see the bottom line).
